What distance function should we use?

children.label: What distance function should we use?

children.value: The k-nearest neighbor classifier fundamentally relies on a distance metric. The better that metric reflects label similarity, the better the classified will be. The most common choice is the

children.html: dist(x,z)=(∑r=1d∣xr−zr∣p)1/p\text{dist}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{z})=\left(\sum_{r=1}^d |x_r-z_r|^p\right)^{1/p}dist(x,z)=(r=1∑d​∣xr​−zr​∣p)1/p

children.value: Assume (and this is almost never the case) we have all knowledge about the distribution. That is we know

children.html: P(X,Y)P(X,Y)P(X,Y)

children.value: distribution from which our samples are drawn
. we can then get every value we want. For example, if we want to have

children.html: P(y∣x)\mathrm{P}(y|\mathbf{x})P(y∣x)

children.value: we just have to use the Bayes rule and calculate

children.html: P(x,y)P(x)\frac{P(\mathbf{x},y)}{P(\mathbf{x})}P(x)P(x,y)​
P(x)=∫y′P(x,y′)P(\mathbf{x}) = \int_{y'} P(\mathbf{x},y')P(x)=∫y′​P(x,y′)

children.value: Therefore, if we know this ultimate distribution, which gives us

children.html: P(y∣x)\mathrm{P}(y|\mathbf{x})P(y∣x)

children.value: , then you would simply predict the most likely label:
\text{The Bayes optimal classifier predicts:}\ y^* =  h_\mathrm{opt}(\mathbf{x}) = \operatorname*{argmax}_y P(y|\mathbf{x})
children.html: The Bayes optimal classifier predicts: y∗=hopt(x)=argmax⁡yP(y∣x)\text{The Bayes optimal classifier predicts:}\ y^* = h_\mathrm{opt}(\mathbf{x}) = \operatorname*{argmax}_y P(y|\mathbf{x})The Bayes optimal classifier predicts: y∗=hopt​(x)=yargmax​P(y∣x)

children.value: 即我们已知对于每个输入 x，输出各个 y 的可能性，那么给一个 x 只需输出最可能的 y 即可

Although the Bayes optimal classifier is as good as it gets, it still can make mistakes. It is always wrong if a sample does not have the most likely label. We can compute the probability of that happening  precisely (which is exactly the error rate):

children.html: ϵBayesOpt=1−P(hopt(x)∣x)=1−P(y∗∣x)\epsilon_{BayesOpt}=1-\mathrm{P}(h_\mathrm{opt}(\mathbf{x})|\mathbf{x}) = 1- \mathrm{P}(y^*|\mathbf{x})ϵBayesOpt​=1−P(hopt​(x)∣x)=1−P(y∗∣x)

: no model can do better than the Bayes optimal classifier.

Figure demonstrating  "the curse of  dimensionality’'. The histogram plots show the distributions of all pairwise distances between randomly distributed points within

children.html: ddd

children.value: -dimensional unit  squares.  As the number of dimensions

children.html: ddd

children.value: grows, all distances  concentrate within a very small range.

children.html: kkk

children.value: NN classifier makes the assumption that similar points share similar labels.
Unfortunately, in high dimensional spaces, points that are drawn from a probability distribution, tend to never be close together. Intuition: 每增加一维度，点之间的距离就再变大一点。
我们假设所有 training data 都在高维的某个 unit hypercube 中。假设

children.html: d=10d=10d=10

children.value: , 对于某个 test point, 我们需要考虑离它最近的10个邻居。有了这10个邻居后，找到一个最小的能够包裹这10个邻居 hypercube，设它的边长为

children.html: ℓ\ellℓ

children.value: , 我们来看看这个 hypercube 的体积。

How about the distance to a hyperplane?  Consider the following figure. There are two blue points and a red  hyperplane. The following plot shows the scenario in 2d and the right plot in 3d. The
distance to the red hyperplane remains unchanged
as the third dimension is added. The reason is that the normal of the hyper-plane is orthogonal to the new dimension. This is a crucial observation.

children.html: ddd
d−1d-1d−1

children.value: dimensions will be orthogonal to the normal of any given hyper-plane. 这

children.html: d−1d-1d−1

children.value: 个维度对离hyperplane的距离毫无影响 **Movement in those dimensions cannot increase or decrease the distance to the hyperplane --- the points just shift around and remain at the same distance. As distances between pairwise points become very large in high dimensional spaces, distances to hyperplanes become comparatively tiny.
The curse of dimensionality has different effects on distances between two points and distances between points and hyperplanes.

An animation illustrating the effect  on randomly sampled data points in 2D, as a 3rd dimension is added (with random coordinates). As the points expand along the 3rd dimension they  spread out and their pairwise distances increase. However, their  distance to the hyper-plane (z=0.5) remains unchanged --- so in relative terms the distance from the data points to the hyper-plane shrinks  compared to their respective nearest neighbors.
However, not all is lost. Data may lie in low dimensional subspace or on sub-manifolds.

The true dimensionality of the  data can be much lower than its ambient space. For example, an image of a face may require 18M pixels, a person may be able to describe this person with less than 50 attributes (e.g. male/female, blond/dark hair, …) along which faces vary.
An example of a data set in 3d that is drawn from an underlying 2-dimensional manifold. The blue points are  confined to the pink surface area, which is embedded in a 3-dimensional  ambient space.
也就是说，前文提到的 curse of dimensionality 并不对实际模型应用起到太大印象，这是因为前面所讲的都是在随机的情况下，然而实际应用的可被预测的数据一般都具有一些隐含的结构（不然它怎么被预测呢）

children.html: kkk

children.value: -NN is a simple and effective classifier if distances reliably  reflect a semantically meaningful notion of the dissimilarity. (It  becomes truly competitive through metric learning)
